Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain and regarding the dictatorial regime of Yemen, Saleh's regime, we have had much more silence than action.

I am not in favor of interference, never have been, but I fear that we are putting ourselves in an uncomfortable position, the position seen from the outside, Mrs. Baroness, which is, instead of helping with development, with aspirations...

Instead of supporting the democratic and revolutionary movements of the peoples in the Arab countries, and helping the First True Arab Spring, what we do is prevent it from spreading, either by excess or by defect, and I don't think we should be burdened with this sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yami activist can serve as a sign that our side is the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, this is a good report by my colleague Mr Casa.
First and foremost, one must ask why revise VAT in the European Union.
First and foremost, the need to make it compatible with the single market
The more regimes and VAT varieties, the less fluid the market will be.
A VAT reform favors e-commerce, centers competition on the value and base price of goods and services, and not on tax differences.
combats fraud and ensures much-needed trust, especially in cross-border transactions, improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other youth-related measures are already in place in the single market that could be linked to VAT?
First and foremost, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, the seventh measure of the single market.
Measure 5, on services, the need to review legislation on standardization and the implementation of the directive on...
the new measure that aims to remove tax obstacles and explicitly review the VAT system and VAT equalisation in online and face-to-face trade that we all feel when we order books.
The pressures for VAT reform have two main reasons.
first of all, the economic crisis
More revenue is needed, including, probably in some countries, reducing contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting that burden to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressures is the aging population, demographic aging, and the trend of shifting from indirect to direct taxes, due to the reduction in the population base for taxation.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to narrow down the range of variation in the standard VAT rate so that we can all understand it better.
Greater transparency is needed in defining the reduced VAT rate and its scope, a clear and widely publicized list of reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, knowing full well that each exemption brings with it a host of small or large-scale frauds.
Finally, welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Madam President, I thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report she has prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly well known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of the Member States harm competitiveness.
The dichotomy between the quality of prices and the complexity of laws and procedures is evident.
It is essential to look at existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has worked well and has facilitated public procurement.
Effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling the public deficit and fostering growth.
To achieve this, it must have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and defend social and environmental values.

That is why I welcome the intentions that Commissioner Barnier has presented to us here for the revision of public procurement, later this year, as one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act. Thank you.
Congratulations to colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the field of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.
Unfortunately, the objectives set by the European Union, 50% of commitments by electronic procedure in 2010, failed, with an average value of only 5%.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are all too evident and have been outlined here. It allows for the replacement of costly access processes with simple consultation of the electronic platform, which means it reduces many costs for companies, especially for SMEs.

small and medium-sized enterprises. Internet dissemination and the ease of receiving procedural documents expand the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing for better purchasing. This makes the process of terminating public contracts...

easier and more flexible, simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby facilitating their participation in the public procurement market, which is crucial for these important drivers of the economy.
In this sense, we welcome and encourage the European Commission for strengthening the mechanisms to make electronic public procurement an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living through decisive hours for the fate of Europe. And while the situation has quickly passed, before everyone's eyes, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a major European problem, the truth is that the inadequacy of the proposed solutions and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The search for solutions targeted at individual states, rather than truly European solutions, allowed the markets to continue speculating about sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and rhythms.
absolutely impossible that some states are trying to achieve with measures of a brutality previously unimaginable applied to people, companies and the public sector.

A common solution is absolutely essential, one that has already been found for the risk of European sovereign debt, which will alleviate market pressure and speculation and provide time for the necessary adjustments to be made.
Without this, what we will end up with are countries that continue to lack the means to pay their creditors, destroyed economies, and a lot, lot of suffering.

I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs, with whom I have had a fruitful collaboration, and I would also like to thank the rapporteurs of the partners from the four committees involved. These partners have made a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 compromises that were all approved.
This demonstrates the importance and interest generated by this topic of new skills and jobs.
It is, after all, about preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to reformulate common ideas to avoid repetition and ensure the report's coherence.
I think that objective has been achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has highlighted the weaknesses of the European economic and social model, and has also negated many of the advances made in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, there are nearly 23 million people without jobs.
Youth unemployment is even more frightening. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21% and is more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all Member States unemployment rates vary with skill levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find jobs more easily.
We also know that in the near future the need for skills, competences and qualifications will increase in all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. First, job creation. Second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Then there is the sustainability of social security systems and finally the difficulty in finding people with the right skills to fill job vacancies.
This report thus has a dual objective. First, to underline the need to act quickly to address skills gaps in Europe. Second, to better anticipate the needs of the labor market in terms of skills.

To achieve this, several measures stand out. First, to ensure the availability of skilled labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I mentioned earlier, skill needs should be identified early, with a time frame of at least 10 years.
Today, we are aware of the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications.
Then, participation in lifelong learning, professional requalification, and reducing school dropout rates must be increased.
Another important issue is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of moving forward with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the link that must exist between educational establishments and the needs of the labour market.
Internships must be of high quality and supervised by tutors so that they can lead to employment and put an end to any abuses of the situation of interns.
Particular emphasis is also placed on the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote job demand and creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we have to create jobs.
And small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in achieving this goal.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, hence the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Lastly, the issue of labour market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labour market, flexicurity rules should be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. I begin by thanking all my colleagues who have spoken in this lively debate.
All colleagues made very useful contributions and contributed to a very constructive discussion on an agenda that is ambitious at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.
Incidentally, this discussion is taking place on the eve of a European Council meeting that will show whether or not there is the political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing.

policy for a deepening of our coordination in economic terms and whether there is really a harmonized and unitary will to be able to carry forward the ambition that is in this agenda. In other words, to have

New jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will give hope to young people who are currently unemployed and those who are currently studying, hope in an inclusive job market that will meet their needs...

ambition of dignification through work and who also have the opportunity to be in a permanent dynamic to keep up with the challenges of a globalized economy with a dynamic that has no parallel in recent generations.

That is why our ambition is truly to create jobs, to have economic growth, not only to respond to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who are entering the job market.

response to the major challenges that lie ahead with the green economy, with health services, with transport services, with accommodation, which require all of us to have a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labor market.
thank you all.

Marisa Matias. Thank you very much, Madam President. What we were told here today in the Council's statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in terms of the European semester. But what we are talking about is a political issue, and the question I pose is whether there can be political coordination without democracy.
Where, after all, is the scrutiny of the European Parliament?
Where is the scrutiny of National Parliaments over their major budgetary choices?

But if the issue were technical, as was stated here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions for the four countries on the waiting list, France, Italy, Hungary, Spain. It did not do the same for the countries under bailout.
So what kind of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to give opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to give opinions about Germany?
And, Commissioner, I ask you only to pay attention to this. No problem of democratic legitimacy is solved by asking Members to consult information on the Internet.
This is a problem of infoexclusion, not a problem of democratic exclusion, which is what we are discussing here.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues. A word of thanks first to the rapporteur from Ardenne for the quality and timeliness of this report, and also to Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is indeed a very serious problem that requires effective and rapid action to stem the rise of the phenomenon, which currently affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are going through has exacerbated this situation and made the times we are living in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of unemployed people continues to rise, and we all know that a lack of employment is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, willingness and a great deal of effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
That is why I warmly welcome the initiative of the Platform Against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
President, access to the internet should now be considered a new fundamental right of citizens and not just a mere object of commerce.
essential things such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism depend on it.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that block free choice and the possibility of easily changing providers, particularly in the mobile telecommunications world, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that complete and transparent information be provided.
Internet shutdowns are not only exclusive to political regimes that are afraid of their own people.
It can also happen as a result of economic choices, by offering privileges to potential customers and less equal treatment to customers who are not as profitable.
That is why I support Parliament in clearly standing up for net neutrality and defending its character of total openness.
Let us speak the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to get out of the crisis and the situation is getting worse day by day.
Instead of healing, we have created two fatal vicious circles.
The first between banks and states.
In Europe, it is now easier to discuss the bankruptcy of a state than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks will finance states and that states will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must push forward with European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
but it is also vital to protect the debt of the States from the attacks of the speculators.

And, to this end, it is urgent and already late to prepare coordinated sovereign debt issues, whether they are called Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and to guarantee them through robust instruments of a Community nature and not an intergovernmental one.
In short, we also need to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

It ignores the essential fact that a single market and a single currency, built by political choice and among unequals, necessarily exacerbates competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And that is what must be attacked in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompoy, through sanctions that promote the crushing of wages and incomes through one country's control over another.
Previously, through a partnership, Mr. Commissioner, between countries with surpluses and those with deficits, we aimed to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
The tensions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and another form of which we cannot speak.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. The Integrated Maritime Policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas and coasts, from a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies related to the sea and requires better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past few years through the various initiatives funded in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy must therefore continue to benefit from adequate funding during the remaining years of the current financial programming period.
In this sense, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, and I support the definition of a stable framework regarding the objectives of this program.

Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics of particular interest to certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The ORs are regions which, with the exception of French Guiana, are remote and small, depend on a limited number of economic activities, and where sea-related and fishing activities are of particular importance.
Furthermore, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the most extensive exclusive economic zone in the world.

The ORs represent more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, and, together with coastal regions, are crucial for the economic growth of the European Union and its member states.

A programme such as the one provided for in the integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions by giving priority to transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
It would be a missed opportunity in the context of integrated maritime policy not to emphasize the enormous potential that the Atlantic and insular dimensions hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and Africa, conferring a strategic dimension to Europe that is indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye to the future.

And it is with the future in mind that the integrated maritime policy, in addition to promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension based on science and technology at the forefront of its priorities.

The investigation of the mid-Atlantic ridge, the deep sea, and the seabeds constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value for the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore take advantage of the Azores' privileged position and the excellence of its oceanographic department to establish a Deep Sea Observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the remedies don't work.
And in the case of the eurozone, excessive remedies have even led to death.
The successive miraculous solutions that have been proposed have also been equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilization Fund, the successive austerity measures of the Stability and Growth Pact, the revenues of the Troika in the low-performing countries.
Blind discipline without growth generated a recessionary wave among fully interconnected economies that therefore contaminated each other with bankruptcies and unemployment.
And at the hands of the markets, that is, the rating agencies and speculators, governments are falling one after another and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Changing the treaties now is another step in this disastrous trajectory, with a major aggravating factor. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty by putting countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to amend the treaties.
In this emergency we are in, we need to make two decisions.
First and foremost, a genuine agenda for sustainable growth and cohesion must be implemented.
Where is the 2020 Agenda?
Where is the relaunch budget?
Where are the so-called projects, the Project Bonds, for Europe's structural investments?
And, secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.
Of course, Eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency we are in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends sovereign debt against speculators.
not in a timid way, but with a definitive, decisive stance, as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that supports it.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties, but rather political will and European conviction.
We will move the treaty when we have learned all the lessons from the present crisis. And there are many lessons to be learned, but this is certainly not the time. Thank you very much.
Mr President and Commissioner Dalli, the first Single Market Forum, an idea stemming from the Grech report, took place in Krakow
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional and local authorities, and civil society.
We have a roadmap laid out in the Commission's communication of 12 April with the 12 levers.
needs to be enacted into law, as does the strategy for the other thirty-eight priorities identified in the act for the single market.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it needs to be stimulated, nurtured.
The single market is not just a buying and selling operation; it involves horizontal policies such as health, social and consumer protection, labor law, the environment, and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should therefore become a flagship event of the European Union, held annually and with a diverse and increasingly participatory audience.
Mr. President, I think we are at a time of assessment regarding these crisis policies, austerity policies that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot help but see how they have generated so much social commotion.

and has generated social confusion not only in the countries with the greatest difficulties, in the countries of the South, not only in the so-called BRIC countries and also in other contexts in Europe.
Just last week, we had the largest general strike in Portugal's history, involving both the public and private sectors, a strike that took to the streets.
But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we witnessed the largest strike ever, especially if we consider that people took to the streets just as they did in Portugal.
and we expect a large demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes prove and the people's taking to the streets proves, is that the causes and the problems we have been facing are common, and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is infecting all member states, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We have witnessed chaos in the financial markets and the growing inability to secure essential financing for the activity of our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for strict budgetary discipline, deep restructuring, and more economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counteract the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that policies aimed at employment and growth are needed, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debts, the central issue today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will collapse.
That is why, more than ever, more than a revision of the treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention by the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. We are all here today united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day and this assessment of the resolution and communication of two thousand and nine is crucial.
It is precisely the things that have already been mentioned that are fundamental.
we repeat because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to be done.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European economic area. A 2010 report speaks of more than 25,000 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about more than a hundred thousand new cases
And if we think that things can't get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues I want to make very clear here has to do with the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
and this disinvestment has seriously affected areas that are crucial for the fight against HIV-AIDS.
That is why, Commissioner, I believe that the Commission has a crucial role to play here in calling on the Member States to fulfil their obligations in these areas.

A second issue is also related to the increase in discrimination, which has also been highlighted by the economic and social crisis, discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because they are importers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for everyone, regardless of gender, age, or the region where they live.
and I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr Draghi.
We are living through special and dramatic circumstances, and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt must be broken, but at the moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the eurozone countries and the euro itself are not destroyed by the rating agencies and speculators.
In the report that we will approve, Tremosa and Vassal, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the eurozone, create eurobonds and a European treasury, but all of this takes time.
At the moment we are talking about an emergency and, in this context, the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, you should not be inhibited in your intervention and action by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Its mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
In a moment like this, there is no doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Draghi.
The European Neighbourhood Policy already included, in a very explicit way, the positions that the European Parliament has been adopting.

And it was with great satisfaction that we saw a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been defending in this House included in the subsequent communications from the Commission and the Council.

I would also like to express my gratitude for the excellent and ongoing collaboration and coordination we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and Commissioner Stefan Füle and their offices.
First and foremost, this is due to the upgrade achieved in our relationship with neighboring peoples.

By prioritizing relations with the general population and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively founded on the universal values that we defend and share.
However, I emphasize that the European Union does not intend to impose a predefined model or formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers' money, we should give more to those who are doing more to approach the values we believe in.
This principle means that the faster a country progresses with its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair and consistent.
Which obviously means that we also anticipate the possibility of there being cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighbourhood policy is now based on the defence of the continuation of common values and a commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.
But this pursuit implies greater accountability.

Our partners are called upon to take more responsibility in the process. That is why we advocate for the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality, and the concept of more for more.

By adopting a bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies, which involve engaging with our partners from the ground up and creating policies that are specifically designed for them, we make development and institutional capacity more effective.

institutional building that we so want to defend and that lies at the foundation of the rule of law and the democratic process, which we want to see implemented as quickly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give a voice to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, supporting organized movements that strive for positive and democratic change in their countries.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, association, religious belief, press, choice, etc.
etc., with fair elections, the fight against corruption, a rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection and resource efficiency.
The serious economic and social problems faced by our neighbors also require immediate action.
It is evident that, without our concrete help, the ongoing democratic processes may fail.
These are the ideas we have always advocated for the future European neighbourhood policy.
These are the proposals contained in the report that we are putting to the vote.
Now is the time to act.
For our part, we will continue to be vigilant and to exercise the new monitoring and oversight powers now conferred upon the European Parliament.

Finally, I would like to thank my colleague, co-ordinator and friend Marek Siwiec, to whom I offer a special word of recognition for his outstanding work on the eastern dimension of the neighbourhood policy.
I would also like to thank the Shadow and Opinion rapporteurs and all of you for the countless suggestions proposed in the amendments you submitted, which I believe have enriched our work.
And a final word to the Secretariat of the Commission and to the political advisors for the excellent support work I have benefited from.
The European Neighbourhood Policy without including the outermost regions as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As external borders, the outermost regions convey our values of democracy, peace, and respect for human rights and fundamental rights to third countries in these regions.
Regions such as the French outermost regions have an absolute need for greater integration into their geographical areas.
far from the Union's internal market, this integration is crucial for their development and represents a huge potential for deepening the neighbourhood policy with neighbouring third countries.

The neighbourhood policy requires a new impetus, one that also takes advantage of the privileged historical and cultural relations that the outermost regions of the Azores, Madeira, and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
These regions can and should play a more active role in support of the European Union within the framework of a new European neighbourhood policy.

Thank you, Mr. President. It was last September, one year ago, after a thorough debate, in which I also participated as the person responsible for this matter in the Socialist Group, promoting meetings and debates with European, national, and regional organizations related to...

For retailers, manufacturers and farmers, Parliament approved the Bouvé report containing an exhaustive set of recommendations to the European Commission aimed at achieving a fair income for farmers and improving the functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, the Commission and Parliament have been producing communications, reports, and recommendations, and establishing high-level forums and groups to address this serious problem, but in practice, nothing has changed beyond increased awareness.

We return to the subject and it must be said without hesitation: a significant part of the problems that farmers face stem from highly penalizing behaviors imposed, above all, by operators of modern distribution.
The problems have been more than identified.
What has been lacking from the Commission and the Member States is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to see losses for farmers and consumers.
to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, it is, above all, dangerous.
First, because it reinforces a recipe that doesn't work with more punishments and rigid rules.
The downward spiral has begun.
Who can trust a doctor who cannot distinguish weight loss from anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more he insists on the medicine, while openly discussing the probability of his death.
How many more countries have to go into recession before the Commission and the Council realise that the diagnosis is wrong?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million and 700 thousand are unemployed.
Almost six million young people have no hope of finding a job.
Doesn't the Council and the Commission realize that ignoring this fact, not giving an adequate response, reveals an autism and insensitivity that are politically explosive?
Let us be clear.
The Great Recession is not a fatality, it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. It must be, however, not of words, but of action.
Where are the Project Bonds to finance European investment?
where is the reinforcement of the European budget with a tax on speculative financial products.
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates imposed on them by the markets, leading them to ruin?
Citizens demand options, not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Madam President. The Commission and the governments now promise to reprogram the structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.

However, it is worth recalling that at the end of last year, the Commission also decided to suspend the allocation of structural funds to countries that do not or did not meet the deficit or debt targets.
One does not need to be a genius to realize that either the promise is fulfilled or the punishment is exacted, but both cannot happen at the same time.
And that is why, Mr Commissioner, I want to ask you a very direct question. Has the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds been maintained, frozen or cancelled?
In other words, can Greece, Portugal, Ireland and other countries still access funds they are entitled to if they do not meet the targets being set by the Commission and by you?
Please respond, Mr. Commissioner. The fact is that in Portugal we are very tired of promises, you know?
Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner. The proposal made by President Barroso to redirect the available structural funds to support our SMEs
and stimulate employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies that are being subjected to strong austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the agreement on external intervention and the major difficulties in financing the economy, and in particular our small and medium-sized enterprises by the banking system, this proposal takes on special importance for regions like the Azores, which have a high absorption and good use of funds, but are in a recessive context.

they can here achieve a real possibility of stimulating their economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our generation of best-prepared young people ever in the best response to growth and employment with these funds...
three options.

President, Commissioner, the milk package that is being presented here as an instrument for organizing the sector contains positive and important elements, such as the strengthening of the role of producer organizations and interprofessional organizations, and contractual aspects that, in some Member States, may, together with the trainers, leave us...

However, this is far from the instruments that the sector needs to thrive in the coming years, within the framework of an agriculture that we want to have in Europe with access to a fair distribution of value in the food chain, that does not turn into an agriculture of large intensive farms concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the condition of self-regulation in the relationship between industry players is desirable, thinking that this alone is sufficient is a serious mistake that could drive thousands of dairy farmers, dozens of regions, and even some countries away from dairy production.
The debate on the regulation of the dairy sector from the perspective of an economically, socially, environmentally, and territorially sustainable sector is still pending.
and we cannot abandon the milk quota system without having ensured genuine instruments for managing supply.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Commissioner. From May 2010 to today, we have seen how a problem that seemed manageable has escalated uncontrollably.
It is true that the fight against the crisis triggered by the financial markets has worsened the debt of the Eurozone countries and that the most vulnerable have become particularly susceptible.

However, is it possible that countries sharing the same currency are left to the mercy of attacks by financial operators and those who profit by betting on the probability of eurozone countries going bankrupt?
The dire consequences of the Commission's failure to respond have generated problems that are now unquestionable.
The speculative interest rates applied to individual countries have made any strategy for exiting the crisis unfeasible.
The consequent worsening of the country's economic problem justifies further interest rate hikes until the total cutoff of credit kills a country's economy and contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long advocated a form of common management of sovereign debt, subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome the fact that the Commission has finally produced a Green Paper on the subject, what has been called...

Today it is clear that without some kind of obligations of this type, properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, the so-called protection barriers, the so-called firewalls for sovereign debt, do not exist. And as long as they do not exist, the euro is in danger and Europe is also in danger.

In the resolution that this Parliament overwhelmingly approved regarding the new Treaty, it became absolutely clear that it is not acceptable to continue imposing more fiscal stability rules, budgetary discipline, and sanctions on the euro countries without taking concrete and urgent steps towards the solidarity-based management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will have to evolve in parallel.
That is what we expect from the Commission, and it is too late now.

I would like to think that this House of European Democracy will unanimously repudiate the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the murder of their own people, which we helplessly witness daily.
Because it is important that Europe can speak with one voice about the significance of the values of respect for human life in the face of indiscriminate and globally orchestrated massacre.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime by implementing new restrictive measures.
The killings have to stop and that is non-negotiable.
insist on dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria needs a transition period and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the application of more restrictive measures against the Syrian regime will not succeed unless all countries are rowing in the same direction. And this has not, unfortunately, happened clearly.
In addition to thousands of deaths and their resolutions being shamefully rejected in the United Nations Security Council,
We continue to disapprove of the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in their unbelievable support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains the same. A power-hungry, desperate, and cornered regime continues to govern a country, and we, the international community, remain powerless to stop the genocide of a people.
We are already far behind in toughening up the action of the European Union and the international community.
We must provide more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must wholeheartedly support the work of the Red Crescent in its efforts to minimize the suffering of the population.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings to punish those responsible for the crimes being perpetrated against humanity.

and as a form of pressure on the countries that have maintained support for Assad, also immediately prohibit the European Union's trade with all Russian or Chinese companies that have commercial relations.
and commissioner yesterday.
Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Madam Commissioner, to discuss this topic of such importance.
In fact, we are talking about central issues related to data protection, especially in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

And data protection is, in fact, one of the sensitive areas that has generated so much controversy and, in my opinion, should continue to generate. Because we are talking about what could be the clash between the...

rights and guarantees, the safeguarding of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and then find themselves overridden when the legislation of other countries supersedes European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
It is sensitive because there is a break and there is doubt in what is a contract that, for all intents and purposes, exists between European citizens and European institutions.
When they provide their personal data, they understand that it will be protected by European entities and institutions and that it will not be distributed for other purposes.

And therefore, there is a breach of trust here and this is a fact that is complicated to manage and, on the other hand, it is also a serious and perilous situation because the European Union ends up transferring personal data to third countries, thus breaking that seal of trust that is generated.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health issues, other issues such as those mentioned by companies.

that require the data, and I am specifically talking, for example, about the case of the United States, which systematically requires data from the European Union, which is what we are doing when citizens assume they are giving up their data and, as I said, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, what is done is a breach of trust.
Therefore, I also want to tell you, Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic for different reasons, but I will always be on the side of the citizens' demonstrations.

who want to safeguard the protection of their personal data. And if there are demonstrations that they believe are necessary because the European institutions do not comply, I think we should be on the side of the citizens and not on the opposite side.

It is almost a kind of betrayal that is being carried out. And that is why we are asking you this question, these questions we are putting to you, Madam Commissioner, so that you can clarify for us once and for all, because no community is built with destruction as its basis or foundation.

weakening of the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And in this regard, Madam Commissioner, please answer us, to what extent can we ensure that European legislation overrides the legislation of third countries?
Because it is true that European legislation overrides the legislation of the 27 member states of the European Union, and citizens abdicate their rights,
In this space of sovereignty, why should we accept that other countries, such as the United States, can then override European legislation that overrides national legislation?
This needs to be clarified because it is indeed very sensitive and serious, and it is an issue we must take into account.

And finally, Madam Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing to prevent this from happening, to ensure it does not recur, and to protect the personal data of all citizens.

The data from companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues are, in fact, data that people can trust, which fall under what we protect. And by this I mean that I don't even share the view that all the information that is stored should be stored, but that is another debate.

Regarding this, as it is a serious issue and a preliminary one in terms of citizens' rights, I would like you to provide us with these clarifications so that we can all feel more at ease. Thank you very much.

Mr President, I would essentially like to say that we expect a major economic decision from the next Council for the countries that are receiving aid, which is closely linked to the issue of structural funds.
Structural funds need to be made more flexible
There are many that are yet to be used, most of them have only been used for large infrastructure projects.
They must be geared towards competitiveness, towards small and medium-sized enterprises, towards relaunching the economy.
The only investment that countries like Greece, like Portugal, like Ireland and like others can have at the moment comes from these structural funds.
it also left a political note for all the politicians of the Union, those who are in good faith in the European process.
When discussing these topics, it is necessary to respect, and to be very careful to respect, the national identities and the Member States.
Politicians, sometimes many of them with good intentions, but not all have been up to the challenge of strict respect for the national identity of each member state.
Thank you, Mr President, Mr President, Commissioner. I salute the rapporteurs and the... But I would like to say that enough is enough of pious speeches about jobs and growth.

Today, with the first results on macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil is beginning to lift on why, in the European Union and particularly in the eurozone, some countries are growing while others are inevitably lagging behind.
Europe is losing competitiveness in foreign markets, and this agenda needs to be revised because much of the insufficient internal growth depends on this. But, focused on the internal market,
Four countries, including Germany, have been accumulating surpluses year after year, while twenty other countries, I repeat, twenty, have been accumulating deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases in an unsustainable manner.
Of course this process has to be controlled,
Of course, discipline is necessary.
But it is important to ask today, in this context, is the solution of crushing the most fragile with recessionary policies the only possible solution?
Is the tax competition of some winners within the internal market still tolerated?

Can the largest European economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while appropriate for its economy, capture most of the gains from the internal market in its favor?
Can the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessionary policies that tighten the economy of the most fragile, discussing
openly discussing the possibility of bankruptcy of sovereign states in the eurozone, when they know that the firewalls have never left the realm of intentions?
Are the Commission and the Council fully aware of the explosive political and economic risk that this discourse brings to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to radically revise the recipes
but for that to happen, there needs to be political will.
Until this will exists, out of respect for the citizens, let us stop saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
and citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.
It is now a commonplace to say that we are experiencing the most serious financial, economic, and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model.
It cannot be stressed enough that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic records, making the fight against unemployment the top priority.
Youth unemployment is dramatic. In my country, Portugal, more than one in three young people are looking for a job and have no prospects of finding one.
Our citizens are disbelieving
It is urgent to restore confidence.
After years of reckless management of public finances, it is time to adopt fiscal consolidation reforms and put the accounts in order.
But let's not kid ourselves, austerity without economic growth is only a partial solution.
Creating more jobs and better jobs is the great European goal.
Measures to ensure that young people do not go more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as reducing the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
A year ago we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
Honoring the victims is telling them that we have learned the lesson, we must learn to deal with natural disasters, and with nuclear ones, we have the obligation to prevent them.
But unfortunately, that doesn't seem to be the truth.
a year after Fukushima, and new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
a year after Fukushima, and new nuclear power plants continue to be planned.
Japan unfortunately has the memory of lasting tragedies, Hiroshima, Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of a lasting tragedy, Chernobyl.
Fukushima forces us, for all these reasons, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two-thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives, they know this cost is priceless. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear power is the policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe too, we have a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and despite this, nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320,000 refugees in Japan. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous. What was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation. It is the ruin of contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited like other ruins, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin. But, nevertheless, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization, and the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
the one that chose to include a deadly technology in its development model.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens have decided to create movements to say goodbye to nuclear power.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is a myth. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests that...
they can simulate what happened in Fukushima. And that's why we know that energy policies are national.
As previously mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
And these are, in fact, the numbers of an epidemic.
And that is why I believe it is also justified to make a specific resolution regarding diabetes, especially since this is the first time this Parliament has addressed this issue.
It is the result of collective work and it is a work that does not nullify the work done so far on chronic diseases; on the contrary, it reinforces this capacity we have to intervene together.
We have about 325,000 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, and failure of vital organs.
And in light of these data, we have two options, in my opinion.
The first is to say that it's not that serious, that we can live well with this and that each government can deal with it.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that, on our side, we have a lot to do.
and we have much to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this resolution has the value of a beginning and of joint work in this direction. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I wanted to draw attention to, basically, was to congratulate you on the Council's results.
not because the measures are ideal, but because they are the possible measures.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many states have been making a huge effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been made in some states by induction of the European Union.
It is essential for them to recover their credibility in international markets and it is essential for them to be able to grow in the long term.
With these guarantees that the states have given, among which the Portuguese state stands out, in terms of fiscal consolidation and budget consolidation, I am...
I am convinced, also with the new treaty signed between the 25, that we will be in a position to seriously relaunch growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But only with this confidence that is being generated little by little is that growth to be made.
And that is why I say that solidarity from the rich towards the poor is important, but solidarity from the poor towards the rich is also important, as it provides these guarantees.
Mr President, I basically wanted to say that it is with great joy that we note that steps have been taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, like Spain or like Greece, which were countries that lived under dictatorships and had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And that is why Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would, in any case, like to give a slightly different note here than the one that has been given by my colleagues.

I know and welcome the great concern for minorities, but we must not forget the Serbian majority. It is crucial that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a full right to be there.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia. And so, much as we emphasize the rights of minorities and they have to be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, their identity and their full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their own state and national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Portugal voted last week on the treaty, or rather, the budgetary ultimatum, which is not, incidentally, a European treaty. It is good to mention that.

The government parties' vote in favor reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good student, who is grateful, doesn't think and obeys the bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to move from a very dangerous violent abstention to a clear vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Assembly of the Republic, the Portuguese one, the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating itself from one of its most important functions for which the people elected it: to decide annually on the country's budget.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, yet another one. It is a blow in which the power of money becomes increasingly out of reach of the citizens' vote.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that one can no longer vote? Thank you.
Fiscal consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, each day there are fewer people who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, yet we are witnessing completely disproportionate tax evasion and avoidance.
The Group of the European Socialists wanted to know how much this tax evasion and avoidance was worth in the 27 countries, and it amounts to one trillion euros.
This is more than the European Union countries spend on health.

This means such a volume that, if we were to spend just a fifth of this amount on investment, investment in Europe would rise from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore talking about an exceptionally high amount.

And the purpose of the resolution we are going to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to accelerate concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for tax cooperation within the European Union, tax cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country in a bilateral manner.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating tax fraud and evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a major partner in the international context
Within the G20 framework, Europe has an obligation to clearly advocate for a common fight against tax fraud and evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens and, therefore, my final words in this debate are a call for the Commission and the Council to begin an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating my colleague Nibler for her excellent work and noting the coincidence that on the Day of Europe, which we celebrate today, we are debating and will approve measures tomorrow that meet the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.

What is at stake in this regulation is to impose limits on mobile phone tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with the ultimate goal of ending roaming within the European area as of 2016.
Our citizens will now benefit from a sharp drop in prices for calls, texts, and data.
If nowadays there are operators that charge 3 euros per mega, from July onwards the maximum price they will be able to charge is 70 cents per mega, with this value dropping to 20 cents in 2014.
As for incoming calls, the maximum price that can be charged will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: higher quality of information for consumers.
Starting in the summer, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices charged when they travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation was only within the European space.
Third advantage, the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer will be able, if they so choose, to have two contracts, one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad, while keeping the same mobile phone number and having only one bill.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be given the option to contract with any European operator that offers the best price.
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
Madam President, in February 2009 this Parliament approved a report supporting the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.
There were projects on clean energy, transport, new technologies, innovation, and even then the role of the European Investment Bank and the structural funds was being considered.
More than three years later, we have been able to produce the Six-Pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the Fiscal Compact, the Two-Pack, all of which are full of reinforced discipline and sanctions.

But meanwhile, as unemployment, especially among the young, reaches alarming levels, the European economy is entering a recession and more than seven of its member countries are experiencing negative growth.
And yet, while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At the moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters now is not to attribute a sense of urgency to it, but a sense of emergency in a situation that threatens to explode.
A set of pillars urgently needs intervention.
First and foremost, the European Marshall Plan must be composed of investments that promote growth, employment, and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare to coordinate sovereign debt issuance and jointly manage the accumulated debt.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to actually function as real firewalls in defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was massively transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks has to reach companies.
A billion euros is held back in the banking system, while thousands of viable companies die every day due to lack of financing.
Fifth point, investment makes no sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that need to stimulate internal demand.

The fact is that almost 80% of trade today is done within Europe. And it is up to the Commission, Mr. Commissioner Olli Rehn, to make recommendations directed not only at the most fragile economies, but also at the most dynamic ones.
And finally, I will conclude now, Mr. President, there must be a limit to the revenues imposed by the troikas.

We must put an end to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which high-ranking officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member countries. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioners. What I wanted to say is very clear. Of course, the Portuguese MEPs from the EPP fully support all measures that can contribute to growth. There is no possibility of...

if we come out of this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those states that are most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I listen to some colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think we can continue to have growth with excessive deficits and more public debt.

Now, we must continue to insist on reducing spending and on structural reforms. We can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of containment and reduction of public spending.

structural reforms. More growth cannot be more relaxation, more rest. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and great rigor in structural reforms.
If we only start talking about growth and think that there are magical solutions to growth, we will end up again with an unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

That being said, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, at the morning summit, it will not only be about this long-term or medium-term issue of growth, but also about the urgent issue of Greece. And I think it is crucial that European states somehow stand by Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem. And I would like to repudiate here the statement made by the British MP who spoke of the Portugalization of Europe.
The Portugalization of Europe, at least on the level of values, would not be a negative thing. And therefore, I reject this idea of trying, in the end, to humiliate or try to diminish any peoples.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.

Thank you very much, Mr President. Commissioner, you came here to tell us that every extra euro spent on debt is a euro less for job creation. So explain to us why we should continue with this obsession.

he came here to tell us that one of the priorities of the Summit is to keep Greece in the Eurozone. And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, do we believe you or do we believe Dr. Durão Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who were saying exactly the opposite a few days ago?
He spoke about maintaining the eurozone, I ask myself, which euro?

in the euro we are currently living in, in this zone we are currently living in, or in the euro that was announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study that referred to a G euro, a second-category euro, in case the left wins the elections in June in Greece.
This is a trap, Mr. Commissioner, it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by governments and it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by financial interests.
Let us not let people live in fear, because that is not a way to live. Europe can be different. You know, it's not a lack of money, it's a lack of shame.

Mr President, Mr Vaman, the first thing I wanted to say is that it is regrettable that the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, Mrs Ashton, is not present for a debate of this importance.
In any case, we are pleased to be working once again with Minister Vaman, who made a statement here that I fully endorse.

I would like, first of all, to offer a word of comfort and solidarity to the Guinean people, who have basically been the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability, and great insecurity.
It was not enough that he was surrounded by poverty; he has been systematically affected by these evils.

I wanted to say, on the other hand, that the EPP, under its presidency, has been following this issue from the beginning and that it is also regrettable that the European Parliament can only manage to have a debate on this matter after a month.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean issue.

And this invisibility is due solely to the fact that, unlike other matters, also very serious, there are no large economic interests at stake here that would motivate the European, American and world powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if an external reason is needed, if the misery and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is an external reason.
less so if the drug trafficking situation that is spreading in Guinea and directly affecting European and American peoples were a reason for us to engage in this.
And that is why I am asking the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, the Community of Portuguese Language Countries, the African Union, but perhaps not yet of the Community of West African States, are moving in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, we need actions.
We need to be firmer, we need to be more effective with the states that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
This is our obligation.

And I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well on the level of principles, but it is not responding as it should on the level of practical instruments, of operation on the ground, and that is what I ask of the Council and I ask of the Commission.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, globalisation has brought with it a disproportionate growth in the financial sector, whose transactions are now, as is well known, seventy times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, very frequent transactions, high compensation, and very high risk have not only come to characterize the world we live in today, but are also fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis came to demand accountability and much more effort from ordinary citizens than from the sector that had caused it.
So today, this moment is important.

It is important and I would personally like to see a situation where the tax is generalized in all European Union countries and subsequently extended to the rest of the world, through active participation of the Commission and the European Union in general in the context of the G20.
I would like it to be covered or to cover all products without exception.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, compromises have to be accepted, but we must not lose sight of the direction in which we need to move.
And this can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission, and with a great spirit of compromise on the part of the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only thank not only Ani Podimata, who was tireless in this process, but also all those who managed to overcome their differences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, colleague Podimata. Today we have discussed here for the first time the tax on financial transactions, and its approval is the first sign that speculation will not go completely unpunished in this crisis we are living through.
This House and the European institutions must answer to the people and not to the financial markets.
For decades, the financial market lobbies have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any problems.
It was obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012 the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.
And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to prevent any action being taken, but also to facilitate a direct transfer from the citizens' pockets to these same speculative markets.

We have been fighting for this for many years, Mr. President, but it was only when the people all over Europe began to say enough is enough that there was finally some initiative on the part of the institutions that govern the European Union.
And so this is the answer we have to give to the citizens. It is a first sign that we have to give.
The citizens of Europe, who have paid for everything, do not deserve for us to lack respect for them.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We have been walking, not us, European leaders have been apologizing to the financial markets
they should apologize to the people they have affected.
And, to conclude, Mr. President, quoting a now famous politician, it is these markets we are talking about, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a sign of trust to the people and I sincerely hope that, with this approval and with the positive vote of my colleagues, we will start to talk about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, gather your courage, let's get this project passed.
Thank you, Mr. President. The financial transaction tax should serve as a way to control and discourage high-risk speculative activities in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and increase healthy competition, the foundation of the single market, and also generate revenue.
The Podimata report attempted to bring the European Commission's initial proposal closer to the UK's well-known Stamp Tax. This made the proposal more appealing to reluctant member states.
The Council is also expected to understand the message.

If in the Commission's proposal the tax applied to transactions of financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union, it is now intended that transactions in European assets, even if carried out by non-Europeans, should also be taxed.
This measure will broaden the revenue base and reduce evasion.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources of the Union or of the States, reducing the taxes of the Member States, a matter still to be decided.
I conclude, Mr. President, by congratulating the rapporteur on the quality of her work and I hope that this symbolic text...
Thank you, Madam President. This weekend we had another request to save the private banking sector.

they keep saying the same argument, which is to prevent contagion to the eurozone. And what I ask is whether we have learned nothing. Greece, Portugal, Ireland and now Spain, and yet the contagion continues.
But what is this containment root of contagion that is destroying us?

This policy doesn't work, we should have known it already. It's the same rulers who say there's no money for culture, education, health, public goods, who, when banks ask the markets, make it appear almost miraculously.
This economic policy is not a remedy, it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
The markets dictate and the governments obey and blackmail the peoples. And that is what the governments are doing with Greece right now, during an election period.

I sincerely hope that it is in the best interest of all of us, the Greek people, not to be blackmailed next Sunday and that they will teach us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, unfortunately, the proposals we are discussing here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the eurozone and also implement the logic of the Fiscal Treaty.

There are some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I refer, for example, to the roadmap for a day when one might begin to think about ways to define possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of Eurobonds.
The problem is that this day will only come when all the problems in the eurozone have been resolved, and that day is late in coming, very late indeed.
We support some aspects of this proposal, but at this pace everything will be too little, too late.
Placing a country under legal protection implies maintaining rates and amounts, as well as prioritizing new loans. In other words, it requires...
Member states that honor their debt are stripped of all and every instrument that could allow them to grow and find the resources to do so.

Let's be frank with each other. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and is provided for is for the creators, but even these will not be resolved, because it is not effective for them either.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and now in Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment and insolvency. And I conclude, Mr President, by saying that the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies brings us closer to a point of no return.
Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German Government are proposing the same policy, but in overdose. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Given the extremely limited time we have, I only want to say at this moment to the Commission that it can count on this...
Parliament in effective work for the solidity of the eurozone and Europe, but this is only achieved when initiatives that focus on discipline are added to

we managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices between the different member states and between the different citizens, and a hope, a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are going through.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are needed, and it is these that this Parliament is trying to fill, an initiative focused on investment, growth, and control.
the sovereign debt that has been the Achilles' heel of those evident reflects the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Commissioner, you can count on us, Council, Madam President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda, it cannot be an agenda that does.
