the discipline or the condition for everything else to follow, nor what makes discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this of us, they can count on Parliament, and I want to thank my colleagues once again, the rapporteurs, Mr. Gozés, who is the other rapporteur, and all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active participants in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
for a more balanced, more solid Parliament project, which I hope will deserve the respect, the capacity for dialogue and the spirit of construction and compromise that it has had so far.
Thank you. Thank you very much, Mr. President. Thank you very much, Madam President. Thank you very much, Commissioner.

Thank you very much, Madam President. In addition to thanking everyone who contributed to this result, I would like to request that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately at the track level.
Today, we are confronted with three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda concerning bank management, and the agenda concerning the management of sovereign debt.
And dealing with the European Semester involves including these three dimensions.
On the issue of growth, I think it is important at this point to emphasize that the Commission's recommendations cannot only focus on...
countries with deficits. They must also affect countries that have surpluses. And if some have to suppress their internal demand, others have to release it.

I also think that, in terms of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called Troika, because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public spending, as if nothing had happened.
The troikas must have their recipe reviewed and adjusted based on the results. And I want to tell you, Mr. Commissioner, that we approve here in Parliament today
Parliament, the need to launch a tool for growth and counter-cyclical activity in the order of 1% of the European Union's GDP for 10 years.

A second dimension that is fundamental is the dimension of what is now called the Banking Union. We requested in Parliament that this be done two years ago, in a report from June 2010. So far it has not been implemented.

A third dimension is the sovereign debt dimension. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. And I also want to say that today we approve the Tupac here, but we introduce in the Tupac, in addition to austerity,

something else has been missing, and that is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using German terminology, so that the sovereign debt, which exceeds sixty percent, can be managed collectively.

This is a legislative text and we expect the Commission's full support for this Parliament initiative, so that we can control the completely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. Now that we intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget citizenship and consumers, in essence, the human and social dimension.

which gives it substance and which was the subject of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Because any growth pact must take into account the sacrifices and social benefits associated with it.

As important as a test of the internal market will be to conduct a social impact test of all measures taken to achieve the single market. A test, yes, an examination that allows us to measure the progress achieved for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is experiencing an unprecedented contraction and unemployment among men, women, and young people is reaching historic records.
According to forecasts by the Bank of Portugal, the situation will worsen in the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Now and always insisting on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, the Member States will really have to focus their efforts on job creation.

The means to achieve this should involve subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, reducing the tax burden on labor, and support for the creation of new businesses and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain jobs.
National employment policies must bear in mind that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are health, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
It is urgent, as stated in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills demanded by the job market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment involves worker mobility.
It is also crucial to consider the use of structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the Euros portal as the primary instrument for recruitment and job offers in Europe.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens are eagerly waiting for concrete results. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Commissioner. It is true that six months have passed since this scandal with the GDP occurred, and the most unbelievable thing is that for ten years a private company could have managed to...
operated in the market and introduced silicone implants that were intended for the construction and manufacture of mattresses and were used in women in 71 countries.
This affected hundreds of thousands of women, as mentioned, it is estimated that around 500,000.

Now, we are talking about estimates because there were failures and serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, it is a fraud, it is a court case, but we also know...

that there is fraud here that must be controlled by the courts and the courts will deal with it. But there is a legal flaw, there is a legal vacuum and we must deal with that. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years we were unable to identify what the criminals were able to identify. And therefore, there was a void in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of the files, in terms of the records. Everything failed. But these gentlemen from this company were able to put into practice what we were unable to control.

This process is not only about the lack of information, which is very important, in fact, the lack of information on all issues related to breast implants, but also about the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who had to undergo tests to find out whether or not they had been fitted with the correct implants.

We are talking about a public health issue, and we cannot be lax when it comes to public health. We regulate so many unnecessary things, we even regulate the authenticity of car parts, and we recently approved a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the Medical Devices Directive is good news. It was the best news that we wouldn't have to do it. But now, since we are going to do it, let's apply it with...

conditions, with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because, unfortunately, sanctions, even if applied, will not be applied to the women who have suffered from this problem, and states must take full responsibility.
Mr President, I wanted to state very clearly here that the Council meeting at the end of June is crucial for us, and that what is essential is that a European solution to this crisis is sought.
From our point of view, the problem so far is that we have been dealing with each of the issues that arise in isolation and individually.

The time has come for us to have a global solution for Europe, a solution that involves, as President Dole has made very clear, more integration, more cooperation, greater alignment of European policies, and a revaluation of the Community method.
It is essential that alongside stability there is growth, but that we do not abandon concerns about stability.
We therefore count on a global European response, not a response divided for each state or for each region in difficulty.
Productive issues and increased production possibilities have led to considerable increases in milk production, creating critical situations, surpluses, and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were sold at bargain prices in the market of other countries, generating even greater downward pressure on the prices paid to producers in those countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk sold in France at double the price it was sold in Galicia. And producers, with the sharp increase in the cost of raw materials and production factors, now find their ability to withstand low prices extremely reduced.

This is a bad prognosis for many farms and many productive territories in Europe, and it also seems to be a clear indication of what the future may hold without quotas and without adequate supply regulation instruments.
It therefore demands a detailed audit of the territorial impacts on thousands of farms across the European Union of abolishing these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Thank you, Mr President. I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur on this report.
This is a matter of utmost importance for Europe.
at a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by combating counterfeit products is crucial for the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation. It should ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All of this with the aim of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years, we have witnessed a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represents annual losses, as mentioned here, of 250 billion euros for companies and the destruction of 185,000 jobs in the European area.

But, in addition to these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc., are falsified,
etc., are produced in unregulated environments.
That is why the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing counterfeit products from entering the internal market.
The revision of this regulation aims to strengthen the control of the application of the legislation in question, reinforce the legitimacy of its intervention, increase the...
legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the Regulation to new realities and developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are thus a crucial priority for achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in order to achieve smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. In fact, the election of the new Egyptian President in the post-Mubarak era is good news. But we cannot delude ourselves and these presidential elections do not in any way close what is the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was rightly pointed out that the dissolution of Parliament days before the presidential elections puts several risks on the table. And in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Superior Council of...

Armed Forces was the least exaggerated. They have legislative power, they reduced the power of the President and, in addition, they still have in their hands the definition of changes in the Constitution.

Now, all of this raises some concerns for us and should raise some concerns for us because the Egyptians risk becoming hostages to military power and a return to the past, lacking a fundamental element which is the democratically elected Parliament.
It is not up to us to bring about change in Egypt, it is up to the Egyptians.
but I think that we Europeans will have to stand by all changes that propose the restoration of what is democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner. I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague, the rapporteur, Lara Comi, on the excellent work she has done on this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a rapidly changing world and society, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrative, effective and up-to-date standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, improves consumer protection and their quality of life, but also protects the environment, is essential.

as well as much more innovation and social inclusion and the interaction and communication of networks and systems, especially in the field, as has already been emphasized here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti noted in his report, a new strategy for the single market, European standardisation is essential for the governance of the internal market, it is emphasised.
There is a need to review the European standardisation process, which should maintain the advantages of the current system and find the right balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are now discussing follows and defends these objectives, which are correct and appropriate. To end the slowness and fragmentation that exists and causes companies to incur costs

transaction costs and higher unit costs, strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardisation activities, particularly at national level, and facilitate their access to these standards, also strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of parties representing the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, and people with disabilities, is maintained, along with financial support for European organizations created to represent public interests.

I conclude by saying that the approval of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner. The future common fisheries policy must give priority to its environmental, economic and social sectors.
in a synergistic and non-hierarchical manner, in the interests of sustainable development and in line with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 Strategy.
As the draftsperson of the REGI opinion, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are heavily dependent on the sector...

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thereby safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that must take into account the disparate realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in various coastal regions.

I argue that this policy should focus on regionalization as a form of governance, through an enhancement of the participation of various stakeholders, so that in the future, a more adequate response to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin can be achieved.
We are reaching the decisive moments when we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe and we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable balances in our heliothermic resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and the promotion of their socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector and in the supply of quality food, require more than ever courage and bold measures.
We must therefore make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, suggesting that the exploitation of its resources be carried out taking into account scientific data, giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploitation, and restricting external access beyond 100 miles to existing fishing banks.
I proposed safeguarding the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities by rejecting the proposals for transferable quotas.

I proposed that our communities have better intervention in the management of their affairs, of fishing, with the creation of a proper Regional Advisory Council, more suitable for the outermost regions. I hope that in this way we can have a better future.

Considering what we know about the implementation of the third package, and part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the delay in transposing its directives, it seems that the latest information I have is that...

18 Member States have been notified, probably this information is already outdated due to lack of transposition. The question I put to you is how you view the possibility of, in the legislation that is being prepared, particularly the networks.
trans-European networks, if it includes a device, an incentive that conditions a conditionality for the submission of PCIs, of projects of common interest.

subject to compliance by Member States with the obligations arising from the third package or, on the contrary, considers that this is an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left only to the regular competition mechanisms, Article 101,
and their successors, all intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
of the Commission and the tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed on this matter. But the question is whether, with legislation in preparation that may...
introducing an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you think that this conditionality is an abusive instrument or do you think that this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share much of the concern that was initially presented here, regarding democratic legitimacy and democratic control that are related to this proposal by the European Union.

Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because an essential issue remains to be clarified and resolved, which is the role of Parliament, the only institution directly democratically elected by citizens.

But there is another concern that I also have, which is a fundamental concern and has to do with the following: monetary policy instruments are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union. And yet, if everything goes wrong, if banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying for that bankruptcy continues to fall on the taxpayers of the National States, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a problem of similar importance, it is a fundamental problem that remains unresolved. And finally, I just want to point out that it also does not resolve the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live, which is inflation, and not to job creation and growth, as it should be. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline, and I ask, budgetary discipline, so let's get to it. Because what exactly are we talking about when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my view, budgetary discipline means respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the state's commitments halfway through. In my view, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies.

Fiscal responsibility means honoring commitments in health, education, and culture, and not closing services or canceling projects halfway through. Discipline means putting banks in order and not taking money from taxpayers to put it in the hands of speculators to save their banks.
This is the fiscal discipline I would like to see implemented in the European Union, rather than continuing with this market party.

If an example is needed, the budget being discussed in Portugal under the Troika is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments that any state must have with its citizens in order not to violate the agreements made behind closed doors that are bringing Europe and its countries together.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr President of the Commission. First of all, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on the Council's results, even though it seems to me that it is a little delayed in time, the final decision is a bit late.
The truth is that there is progress.
Now, precisely because I agree with everything my colleague Cassolides has said, I would like to ask just one question to the President of the Council. The countries that are under assistance...
countries that are in difficulties have fought hard to ensure that there can be a retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from state debt.
This apparently was not accepted.
But we heard statements yesterday from the highest German authorities and the highest French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland as a special case.
What I am asking is whether the Council has approved any decision to apply discriminatory treatment to Ireland different from that reserved for countries like Portugal, Greece, Spain and others.
Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses.
regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, which marks the twentieth anniversary of this market.

A first word to thank my colleagues from all the political groups and, in particular, the draftsmen of opinions and the shadow rapporteurs, for their very constructive contributions and their very positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone and the report greatly benefited from our combined effort.

We are well aware of and proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been the driving force behind major economic and employment opportunities in Europe, which have transformed the lives of European citizens and European businesses.
travelling, residing and working within the Union's area are freedoms that are within reach of all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis,
2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs that were created and the additional 2.13% GDP growth.
Today, making a phone call or receiving a call while traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people is most eloquently expressed in the Erasmus program.
More than 2.5 million students have benefited from this European Programme for Education and Mobility Exchange.
In the past five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% cut in administrative positions due to single market legislation.
But one question arises. Is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.
Our citizens, in some countries living with the drama of unemployment and facing austerity measures, have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative view of the internal market.
People still do not know or sufficiently understand their rights, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States are unduly delaying the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thereby undermining its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, such simple things as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another EU country, or opening a bank account by a student in the program...

Erasmus, changing energy supplier, transferring retirement pensions, having qualifications recognised and registering a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult or costly procedures.
It is important to address these problems.
That was my concern as rapporteur.
That is why the message written in the report is very clear: more political will is needed, much more political will from the member states and the European institutions.

Council, especially the Council and the Commission, to govern better and together. It is necessary to regain the trust of people and companies and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to commend the European Commission, represented by Commissioner Barnier, for presenting the Act for the Single Market 2, 12 priority actions for new growth, which I am sure marks a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier, dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your already very successful efforts.
When Jacques Delors chaired the European Commission, the Union's Single Market was created in 1992.
Delors then summarized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years on, the economic and financial crisis has reignited the threat of national protectionism, and it has become clear that the internal market is not a finished work.

And the celebration of these 20 years must be used to relaunch the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To do this, it is necessary to set priorities, and I would like to talk about one priority in particular.
A common policy is essential to produce and distribute energy at affordable prices for consumers, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructure, with the possibility of leveraging community investment that represents added European value.
In energy too, Madam President, it will dominate the common market.
one of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which certainly represents one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its Member States and its regions.
However, in order to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies towards equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue to increase their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions. But we will never achieve this if we do not better address our accessibility problems in the area of transport.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that better address the problems raised by our separation.
We therefore argue that the Commission should consider a specific programme, such as POSEI Transport, as an essential instrument for integrating these types of regions into the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to begin by saying thank you very much for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is truly a great achievement of the European project.

I welcome the presence of Mr. Minister Mavroianis and his participation in this debate. I thank all my colleagues for their constructive attitude, some of them with a skeptical attitude, which is understandable.
and say a big thank you to Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he puts into discussing these issues, these problems of the internal market and the political will to solve them.
We still have a lot to answer to the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, disillusioned and expect more from us, expect more from the Council, expect more from the Commission, expect more from the Member States.
This balance sheet is very useful, this 20-year balance sheet is important, but, as many have said here, it is important to open the door to the gaze of the future.
And the forward-looking approach addresses many of the issues that have been raised here and many of the measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The digital single market, citizen mobility, the reform of the EURES portal, and the European energy market are examples.
eloquent proof that we still have an important path to follow in the future and that this path is very important and vital to respond to this era of crisis that we are experiencing.
Citizens are suffering, citizens expect a lot from politicians and the answers that politicians can give to the adverse conditions they are experiencing.
That is why it is important that the single market is one of the answers to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this 20th anniversary celebration, are more eager to provide the answers our citizens need. Thank you very much.

The Gozes report, along with the report we will prepare on the Union's annual growth prospects at the end of this year, which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential parts of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council on the proposal of the Commission. And these recommendations, as was just mentioned, align with...
The SIXPEC and the future TUPEC, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policy of member countries.

The balance between this control and autonomy and legitimacy at the national level is not easy to find and it has fallen to a level of imposition, especially of discipline and, ultimately, it can even result in a serious package of sanctions.

Regarding Tupac, I would like to briefly comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent today, to give its negotiators a negotiating mandate that is compatible with the ambition to quickly conclude this package, this Tupac.

But more European coordination, to return to the topic, means less control of countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between medium and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment and real convergence, and short-term recommendations, which are mainly focused on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be coherence

with the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, particularly the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, we need to agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic and labour rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. And finally, it is important that the quality of the recommendations is measured by the results achieved, which is far from being the case so far.

I will conclude now, Mr President. I just wanted to thank Mr Gozes for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he will take another step in this spirit, in order to broaden the consensus base around his report and that this spirit will also remain in relation to the next one.
It is true, and it has been mentioned here many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
but there are also many that we already know and it is important not to forget them.

We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation uses an additional 19 million litres of drinking water, which is enough to supply a thousand European citizens for a year in terms of their needs.

We also know that with each shale gas extraction, in each of the operations, 300, excuse me, tons of chemicals are pumped into the ground, and about 80% of them remain in the ground and don't come out.

We also know that radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsoil during each shale gas extraction, which, along with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of drinking water resources and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also a response that is apparently easy, that only thinks about the immediate, the industry and profit, ignoring the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, in this House, that water is an essential, vital and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and health standards.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, being prudent is the minimum.
And they may even want to do so, but do not do it in our name or in the name of the citizens who are here for us to represent.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, indeed, the last few years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
they also showed us that we had a European institutional architecture full of holes, in particular the institutional architecture of the euro.
And that is why the report that is presented here and the proposal that is put forward is so many efforts ahead in terms of ambition compared to what is presented by the governments.

But also, as the rapporteur said, we are in a position of making political choices and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and will not be able to support this report.
The first has to do with issues related to conditionalities.

What we see is that we continue to have a narrative in which solidarity between different countries can only exist when everything is fulfilled in terms of the stability and growth plan, in terms of the intergovernmental agreement, pact for...
The euro plus is a set of measures that impose nothing but massive doses of austerity in the peripheries and also a set of recessionary measures that, as we have seen, are not working.
A second reason has to do with the Banking Union.

The rapporteur very well presents the banking supervision mechanism, but it is so necessary that we cannot shy away from the essential. And the essential here is getting away to the extent that we continue to add up the...

national systems are agglomerated, which means that we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong and therefore taxpayers will continue to pay.
And a third point concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of Eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of issuing common debt is considered, but only when it is already too late.

because we need the debt as it is now, not just when the deficits and excessive debts have been corrected, because with these policies we are following, they will never be corrected, on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire set of populations.

So I want to conclude, Mr. President, by saying that despite all the efforts, I think we have here a very clear example that together we could still stand up, but divided we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to go even further.
There is always room for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union has been crucial in recent years.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country with highly trained, highly sophisticated labor.
But when the country exports, it is necessary to have conditions for where?

And that is why it is important that some countries with surpluses open their doors to the requalified exports of countries that started with a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

One final note to say that it is not possible for immigration to be the solution, that the requalified workforce and where support from the European Union was used is now lost through a massive export of the most qualified to countries that have the margin to welcome them.
This is dramatic and completely jeopardizes our future. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr President. Small-scale fishing should be given special protection under the common fisheries policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihood of many families, but also because it is a factor in retaining these communities along the coastal areas.
Their economic and social sustainability must be an objective, ensuring them a differentiated fishing regime that gives priority of access to resources.
allows for proximity management and protects the fishing rights that benefit the fishing professionals of these communities against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important, for their sustainability, to pay attention to the water access regime, especially in waters or regions with biogeographical basins.
marine areas with a reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that must have protected access.
In a context of liberalisation and crisis affecting fragile regions, it must also be ensured that products from international trade meet the same requirements as those imported by the Union.
Mr President, Mr President-in-Office, Commissioner, I shall be very brief because I believe that what is at issue here is essentially a political point.
It is a financial issue. And the question that arises is whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis or if we want to exacerbate the crisis.
Most European countries are currently making a huge effort, in terms of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive way, in a way that can put their countries...
The European Union, on a global scale, has a great capacity for competition and rivalry, but it is obvious that without investment, there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge...
effort, they will not be able to grow and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail. Good accounts with prospects for growth and competitiveness.

The only and great instrument for this is precisely this multiannual financial framework. And therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and for its policy to be an exemplary policy for other countries, we must bet on the budget for the financial perspectives.
